Description: Egyptian ceramic 'dolphin style' oil lamp. Mould-made. The reservoir is round with a cenral hole in the top with a concentric ring modelled around it. The nozzle projects from the body, and flares out at the tip. Traces of burning through use. Red-brown micaceous Nile silt. Lug off the central reservoir is now broken.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Bolton Museum. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Similar Egyptian parallels dating to the 2nd and 1st centuries BC are in the British Museum (Bailey 1975, British Museum Lamps I, see Q551 and Q552 for form, see Q559 for design). Athribis parallels from mid to late 2nd century BC contexts (Mlynarczyk 1997, 45-6, Type F, Fig. 48, who prefers a 2nd century BC date for these). Mlynarczyk, J. 1997. Alexandrian and Alexandria-influenced mould-made lamps of the Hellenistic period. BAR International Series 677. Mlynarczyk, J. 1998. Terracotta mould-made lamps in Alexandria (Hellenistic to Late Roman period), in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 327-52.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.014) (Phase 1)
